entry.q: They . . . have filled all our law books with the obtunding story of their suits and trials.

entry.ety: L. obtundens, p. pr. of obtundere
entry.def: A substance which sheathes a part, or blunts irritation, usually some bland, oily, or mucilaginous matter; -- nearly the same as demulcent.
That which obtunds or blunts; especially, that which blunts sensibility.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Obturated; p. pr. & vb. n. Obturating
entry.def: To stop or close, as an opening;
to stop (a gun breech) so as to prevent the escape of gas in firing.

entry.ety: L. obturare to stop up: cf. F. obturation
entry.def: The act of stopping up, or closing, an opening.
entry.q: Deaf by an outwardobturation.

entry.ety: NL., fr. L. obturare to stop up: cf. F. obturateur

sn.def: That which closes or stops an opening.
An apparatus designed to close an unnatural opening, as a fissure of the palate.
Any device for preventing the escape of gas through the breech mechanism of a breech-loading gun; a gas check.
A camera shutter.

cs.cd: an opening situated between the public and ischial parts of the innominate bone and closed by the obturator membrane; the thyroid foramen.

entry.def: Serving as an obturator; closing an opening; pertaining to, or in the region of, the obturator foramen; as, the obturator nerve.
See Obstuseangular.

entries.entry:
Ob*tuse". a.
Compar. Obtuser; superl. Obtusest
L. obtusus, p. p. of obtundere to blunt: cf. F. obtus. See Obtund
Not pointed or acute; blunt; -- applied esp. to angles greater than a right angle, or containing more than ninety degrees.
Not having acute sensibility or perceptions; not alert, especially to the feelings of others; dull; stupid; as, obtuse senses.
Dull; deadened; as, obtuse sound.

entry.def: Having an obtuse angle; as, an obtuse-angled triangle.
In an obtuse manner.
State or quality of being obtuse.

entry.ety: L. obtusio, from obtundere to blunt. See Obtund

sn.def: The act or process of making obtuse or blunt.
The state of being dulled or blunted; as, the obtusion of the senses.

entry.def: Obtuseness.
Overhanging; as, obumbrant feathers.

entry.ety: L. obumbratus, p. p. of obumbrare to overshadow, cloud; ob + umbrare to shade
entry.def: To shade; to darken; to cloud.
Act of darkening or obscuring.

entry.ety: L. obuncus; obsee Ob-) + uncus hooked
entry.def: Hooked or crooked in an extreme degree.

entry.ety: L. obvention, fr. obvenire to come before or in the way of, to befall; obsee Ob-) + venire to come: cf. F. obvention
entry.def: The act of happening incidentally; that which happens casually; an incidental advantage; an occasional offering.
entry.q: Tithes and otherobventions.
Legacies bequeathed by the deaths of princes and great persons, and other casualities and obventions.

entry.ety: L. obversans, p. pr. of obversari to hover before; obsee Ob-) + versare to move about
entry.def: Conversant; familiar.

entry.ety: L. obversus, p. p. of obvertere. See Obvert
entry.def: Having the base, or end next the attachment, narrower than the top, as a leaf.

entry.ety: Cf. F. obverse obvers. See Obverse a.

sn.def: The face of a coin which has the principal image or inscription upon it; -- the other side being the reverse.
Anything necessarily involved in, or answering to, another; the more apparent or conspicuous of two possible sides, or of two corresponding things.
sn.q: The fact that it [a belief] invariably exists being the obverse of the fact that there is no alternative belief.

entry.def: In an obverse manner.

sn.def: The act of turning toward or downward.

The act of immediate inference, by which we deny the opposite of anything which has been affirmed; as, all men are mortal; then, by obversion, no men are immortal. This is also described as “immediate inference by privative conception.”

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Obverted; p. pr. & vb. n. Obverting
entry.ety: L. obvertere; obsee Ob-) + vertere to turn. See Verse
entry.def: To turn toward.
entry.q: If its base be obverted towards us.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Obviated; p. pr. & vb. n. Obviating
entry.ety: L. obviare; obsee Ob-) + viare to go, fr. via way. See Voyage

sn.def: To meet in the way.
sn.q: Not to stir a step to obviate any of a different religion.

sn.def: To anticipate; to prevent by interception; to remove from the way or path; to make unnecessary; as, to obviate the necessity of going.
sn.q: To lay down everything in its full light, so as to obviate all exceptions.

entry.def: making impossible or unnecessary.
The act of obviating, or the state of being obviated.

entry.ety: L. obvius; obsee Ob-) + via way. See Voyage

sn.def: Opposing; fronting.
sn.q: To the evil turn My obvious breast.

sn.def: Exposed; subject; open; liable.
sn.q: Obviousto dispute.

sn.def: Easily discovered, seen, or understood; readily perceived by the eye or the intellect; plain; evident; apparent; as, an obvious meaning; an obvious remark.
sn.q: Apart and easy to be known they lie, Amidst the heap, and obvious to the eye.

entry.ety: L. obvolutus, p. p. of obvolvere to wrap round; obsee Ob-) + volvere to roll
entry.def: Overlapping; contorted; convolute; -- applied primarily, in botany, to two opposite leaves, each of which has one edge overlapping the nearest edge of the other, and secondarily to a circle of several leaves or petals which thus overlap.
See Obi.
A Peruvian name for certain species of Oxalis Oxalis crenata, and Oxalis tuberosa) which bear edible tubers.
A kind of small simple wind instrument.
An alloy imitating gold or silver.

entry.cs: On occasion in case of need; in necessity; as convenience requires. “That we might have intelligence from him on occasion,” De Foe. occasionally; from time to time; now and then.
entry.ety: F. occasion, L. occasio, fr. occidere occasum, to fall down; obsee Ob-) + cadere to fall. See Chance, and cf. Occident

sn.def: A falling out, happening, or coming to pass; hence, that which falls out or happens; occurrence; incident; event.
sn.q: The unlooked-for incidents of family history, and its hidden excitements, and its arduous occasions.

sn.def: A favorable opportunity; a convenient or timely chance; convenience.
sn.q: Sin, taking occasion by the commandment, deceived me.
I'll take the occasion which he gives to bring Him to his death.

sn.def: An occurrence or condition of affairs which brings with it some unlooked-for event; that which incidentally brings to pass an event, without being its efficient cause or sufficient reason; accidental or incidental cause.
sn.q: Her beauty was the occasion of the war.

sn.def: Need; exigency; requirement; necessity; as, I have no occasion for firearms.
sn.q: After we have served ourselves and our own occasions.
When my occasions took me into France.

sn.def: A reason or excuse; a motive; a persuasion.
sn.q: Whose manner was, all passengers to stay, And entertain with her occasions sly.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Occasioned ŏk*kā"zhŭnd; p. pr. & vb. n. Occasioning
entry.def: To give occasion to; to cause; to produce; to induce; as, to occasion anxiety.
entry.q: If we inquire what it is that occasions men to make several combinations of simple ideas into distinct modes.

entry.def: Capable of being occasioned or caused.

cs.cd: some circumstance preceding an effect which, without being the real cause, becomes the occasion of the action of the efficient cause; thus, the act of touching gunpowder with fire is the occasional, but not the efficient, cause of an explosion.

sn.def: Occuring at times, but not constant, regular, or systematic; made or happening as opportunity requires or admits; casual; incidental; as, occasional remarks, or efforts.
sn.q: The . . . occasional writing of the present times.

sn.def: Produced by accident; as, the occasional origin of a thing.
Of or pertaining to an occasion or to occasions; intended for a specific occasion; for use only when needed, and not regularly.

entry.def: The system of occasional causes; -- a name given to certain theories of the Cartesian school of philosophers, as to the intervention of the First Cause, by which they account for the apparent reciprocal action of the soul and the body.
Quality or state of being occasional; occasional occurrence.
In an occasional manner; on occasion; at times, as convenience requires or opportunity offers; not regularly.
entry.q: The one, Wolsey, directly his subject by birth; the other, his subject occasionally by his preferment.

entry.def: To occasion.
entry.q: The lowest may occasionate much ill.

entry.def: One who, or that which, occasions, causes, or produces.

entry.ety: L. occasivus, fr. occasus a going down, setting of the heavenly bodies, fr. occidere to fall or down. See Occasion
entry.def: Of or pertaining to the setting sun; falling; descending; western.

entry.ety: L. occaecatio, fr. occaecare to make blind; ob + caecare to blind, fr. caecus blind
entry.def: The act of making blind, or the state of being blind.
entry.q: This inwardoccecation.

entry.ety: F., fr. L. occidens occidentis, fr. occidents, p. pr. of occidere to fall or go down. See Occasion
entry.def: The part of the horizon where the sun last appears in the evening; that part of the earth towards the sunset; the west; -- opposed to orient. Specifically, in former times, Europe as opposed to Asia; now, also, the Western hemisphere.
entry.q: I may wander from east to occident.

sn.def: Of, pertaining to, or situated in, the occident, or west; western; -- opposed to oriental; as, occidental climates, or customs; an occidental planet.
Possessing inferior hardness, brilliancy, or beauty; -- used of inferior precious stones and gems, because those found in the Orient are generally superior.

entry.def: Western Christians of the Latin rite. See Orientals.

entry.ety: L. occiduus, fr. occidere to go down
entry.def: Western; occidental.

cs.cd: the bone which forms the posterior segment of the skull and surrounds the great foramen by which the spinal cord leaves the cranium. In the higher vertebrates it is usually composed of four bones, which become consolidated in the adult.
the point of the occiput in the mesial plane farthest from the ophryon.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to the occiput, or back part of the head, or to the occipital bone.
The occipital bone.

entries.entry:
Oc*cip"i*to-. See Occiput
A combining form denoting relation to the occiput, or situation near the occiput; as, occipito-axial; occipito-mastoid.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to the occipital bone and second vertebra, or axis.

entries.entry:
Oc"ci*put n.; pl. L. Occipita #, E. Occiputs. L., fr. obsee Ob-) + caput head. See Chief
Anat The back, or posterior, part of the head or skull; the region of the occipital bone.
Zoöl A plate which forms the back part of the head of insects.

entry.ety: L. occisio, fr. occidere occisium, to cut down, to kill; obsee Ob-) + caedere to cut
entry.def: A killing; the act of killing.

entry.ety: L. occludere occlusum; obsee Ob-) + claudere to shut

sn.def: To shut up; to close.
To take in and retain; to absorb; -- said especially with respect to gases; as, iron, platinum, and palladium occlude large volumes of hydrogen.

entry.ety: L. occludens, p. pr. of occludere
entry.def: Serving to close; shutting up.

def2.def: That which closes or shuts up.

entry.ety: L. occlusus, p. p. See Occlude
entry.def: Shut; closed.

cs.cd: the phenomenon of absorbing gases, as exhibited by platinum, palladium, iron, or charcoal; thus, palladium absorbs, or occludes, nearly a thousand times its own volume of hydrogen, and in this case a chemical compound seems to be formed.

sn.def: The act of occluding, or the state of being occluded.
sn.q: Constriction and occlusion of the orifice.

sn.def: The transient approximation of the edges of a natural opening; imperforation.

entry.def: To incrust; to harden.

cs.cd: a line drawn as a part of the construction of a figure or problem, but not to appear in the finished plan.
those qualities whose effects only were observed, but the nature and relations of whose productive agencies were undetermined; -- so called by the schoolmen.
those sciences of the Middle Ages which related to the supposed action or influence of occult qualities, or supernatural powers, as alchemy, magic, necromancy, and astrology.

entry.ety: L. occultus, p. p. of occulere to cover up, hide; obsee Ob-) + a root prob. akin to E. hell: cf. F. occulte
entry.def: Hidden from the eye or the understanding; invisible; secret; concealed; unknown.
entry.q: It is of an occult kind, and is so insensible in its advances as to escape observation.

entry.def: To eclipse; to hide from sight.

entry.cs: Circle of perpetual occultation. See under Circle.
entry.ety: L. occultatio a hiding, fr. occultare, v. intens. of occulere: cf. F. occultation. See Occult

sn.def: The hiding of a heavenly body from sight by the intervention of some other of the heavenly bodies; -- applied especially to eclipses of stars and planets by the moon, and to the eclipses of satellites of planets by their primaries.
The state of being occult.
sn.q: The reappearance of such an author after those long periods of occultation.

sn.def: Hidden; secret.
Concealed by the intervention of some other heavenly body, as a star by the moon.

entry.def: Same as Occultation.

sn.def: A certain Oriental system of theosophy.
Belief in occult powers or in supernatural forces other than the God of traditional religions, such as in magic, necromancy, alchemy, and astrology.
The study and alleged use of supernatural agencies as in magic, astrology, witchcraft, alchemy, necromancy, spiritualism (communication with the dead), and fortune-telling.

entry.def: An adherent of occultism.
In an occult manner.
State or quality of being occult.

cs.cd: a right of property acquired by taking the first possession of a thing, or possession of a thing which belonged to nobody, and appropriating it.

sn.def: The act of taking or holding possession, especially of real property or rental property; possession; occupation.
The state or condition of being occupied; as, occupancy by more than 250 people is dangerous and unlawful.
The period of time during which one occupies a property.

entry.note: ☞ This word, in law, sometimes signifies one who takes the first possession of a thing that has no owner.
entry.ety: L. occupans, p. pr. of occupare: cf. F. occupant. See Occupy

sn.def: One who occupies, or takes possession; one who has the actual use or possession, or is in possession, of a thing; as, the occupant of the apartment is not at home.
A prostitute.

entry.ety: L. occupatus, p. p. of occupare. See Occupy
entry.def: To occupy.

cs.cd: a bridge connecting the parts of an estate separated by a railroad, a canal, or an ordinary road.

sn.def: The act or process of occupying or taking possession; actual possession and control; the state of being occupied; a holding or keeping; tenure; use; as, the occupation of lands by a tenant.
That which occupies or engages the time and attention.

The principal business of one's life; the principal work by which one earns one's livelihood; vocation; employment; profession; calling; trade; avocation; as, these days many people continue to practice their occupation well into their seventies.
sn.q: Absence of occupation is not rest.
sn.syn: Occupancy; possession; tenure; use; employment; avocation; engagement; vocation; calling; office; trade; profession.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to an occupation{3} or occupations{3}; caused by or incidental to an occupation{3}; as, occupational hazard; occupational illness.

sn.def: Engaged; in use; being used by a person and not free for use by someone else; as, the wc is occupied . Opposite of free available, and unoccupied.
Overrun, taken over; -- of countries or territories; as, occupied France. Opposite of unoccupied.
Busy; actively or fully engaged in some activity; -- of people. Opposite of idle.
One who occupies, or has possession.
One who follows an employment; hence, a tradesman.
sn.q: Merchants andoccupiers.
The occupiers of thy merchandise.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Occupied; p. pr. & vb. n. Occupying
entry.ety: OE. occupien, F. occuper, fr.L. occupare; obsee Ob-) + a word akin to capere to take. See Capacious

sn.def: To take or hold possession of; to hold or keep for use; to possess.
sn.q: Woe occupieth the fine [end] of our gladness.
The better apartments were already occupied.

sn.def: To hold, or fill, the dimensions of; to take up the room or space of; to cover or fill; as, the camp occupies five acres of ground.
To possess or use the time or capacity of; to engage the service of; to employ; to busy.
sn.q: An archbishop may have cause to occupy more chaplains than six.
They occupied themselves about the Sabbath.

sn.def: To do business in; to busy one's self with.
sn.q: All the ships of the sea, with their mariners, were in thee to occupy the merchandise.
Not able to occupy their old crafts.

sn.def: To use; to expend; to make use of.
sn.q: All the gold that was occupied for the work.
They occupy not money themselves.

sn.def: To have sexual intercourse with.
To hold possession; to be an occupant.
sn.q: Occupytill I come.

sn.def: To follow business; to traffic.

entry.def: the act of taking occupancy.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Occurred; p. pr. & vb. n. Occurring
entry.ety: L. occurrere occursum; obsee Ob-) + currere to run. See Course

sn.def: To meet; to clash.
sn.q: The resistance of the bodies they occur with.

sn.def: To go in order to meet; to make reply.
sn.q: I must occur to one specious objection.

sn.def: To meet one's eye; to be found or met with; to present itself; to appear.
sn.q: In Scripture, though the word heir occur, yet there is no such thing as “heir” in our author's sense.

sn.def: To happen; to take place; as, I will write if opportunity occurs .
To come to the mind; to arise in the mind; to suggest itself; to be presented to the imagination or memory; -- of an idea or thought; as, it never occurred to me to call John to ask.
sn.q: There doth not occur to me any use of this experiment for profit.

sn.def: A coming or happening; as, the occurence of a railway collision.
sn.q: Voyages detain the mind by the perpetual occurrence and expectation of something new.

sn.def: Any event or incident; esp., one which happens without being designed or expected; as, an unusual occurrence, or the ordinary occurrences of life.
sn.q: All the occurrence of my fortune.

entry.ety: L. occurrens -entis, p. pr. of occurrere: cf. F. occurrent. See Occur
entry.def: Occurring or happening; hence, incidental; accidental.

sn.def: One who meets; hence, an adversary.
Anything that happens; an occurrence.
sn.q: These we must meet with in obvious occurrents of the world.

entry.def: Same as Occursion.
A meeting; a clash; a collision.

entry.ety: F. océan, L. oceanus, Gr. 'wkeano`s ocean, in Homer, the great river supposed to encompass the earth

sn.def: The whole body of salt water which covers more than three fifths of the surface of the globe; -- called also the sea, or great sea.
sn.q: Like the odor of brine from the ocean Comes the thought of other years.

sn.def: One of the large bodies of water into which the great ocean is regarded as divided, as the Atlantic, Pacific, Indian, Arctic and Antarctic oceans.
An immense expanse; any vast space or quantity without apparent limits; as, the boundless ocean of eternity; an ocean of affairs.
sn.q: You're gonna need an ocean Of calamine lotion.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to the main or great sea; as, the ocean waves; an ocean stream.
Bordering an ocean; as, oceanfront property.
Land bordering an ocean.
capable of crossing an ocean; used on the high seas; -- used mostly of ships; as, oceangoing vessels.
A large group of islands in the south Pacific sometimes including Australasia and the Malay Archipelago.

sn.def: Of or pertaining to the ocean; found or formed in or about, or produced by, the ocean; frequenting the ocean, especially mid-ocean.
sn.q: Petrels are the most aërial and oceanic of birds.

sn.def: Of or pertaining to Oceania or its inhabitants.

entry.def: Same as Oceania.
A daughter of the Titans Oceanus and Tethys.
A scientist who studies physical and biological aspects of the seas.
A description of the ocean.
That branch of science which relates to the ocean.
The god of the great outer sea, or the river which was believed to flow around the whole earth.
Of or pertaining to ocelli.
Same as Ocellated.

cs.cd: the wild turkey of Central America (Meleagris ocellata).

entry.ety: L. ocellatus, fr. ocellus a little eye, dim. of oculus an eye

sn.def: Resembling an eye.
Marked with eyelike spots of color; as, the ocellated blenny.

entries.entry: ‖O*cel"lus n.; pl.Ocelli #. L., dim. of oculus an eye Zoöl A little eye; a minute simple eye found in many invertebrates. An eyelike spot of color, as those on the tail of the peacock.

entry.def: Resembling the ocelot.

An American feline carnivore (Felis pardalis). It ranges from the Southwestern United States to Patagonia. It is covered with blackish ocellated spots and blotches, which are variously arranged. The ground color varies from reddish gray to tawny yellow.

entry.ety: F. ocre, L. ochra, fr. Gr. �, from (�) pale, pale yellow

sd.def: A impure earthy ore of iron or a ferruginous clay, usually red (hematite) or yellow (limonite), -- used as a pigment in making paints, etc. The name is also applied to clays of other colors.
A metallic oxide occurring in earthy form; as, tungstic ocher or tungstite.

sn.def: The color of ocher{1}, varying around orange, from more yellowish to more reddish in tint.

entry.ety: A humorous variation on the term amber mutation
entry.def: A mutation in which the base sequence of one of the codons in the messenger RNA has been converted to UAA. Such a mutation may be conditionally suppressed, as can an amber mutation, by the presence of a special transfer RNA.
Of or pertaining to ocher; containing or resembling ocher; as, ocherous matter; ocherous soil.
Ocherous.
See Occamy.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. � disturbance, fr. 'o`chlos crowd, mob
entry.def: A general morbid condition induced by the crowding together of many persons, esp. sick persons, under one roof.

entry.ety: Gr. �; 'o`chlos the populace, multitude + kratei^n to be strong, to rule, kra`tos strength: cf. F. ochlocratie
entry.def: A form of government by the multitude; a mobocracy; mob rule.
Of or pertaining to ochlocracy; having the form or character of an ochlocracy; mobocratic.
A natural family of mammals including pikas and extinct forms.
Ocherous.
See Ocher.

entries.entry:
‖O"chre*a n.; pl.Ochreæe #. L
Antiq A greave or legging.
Bot A kind of sheath formed by two stipules united round a stem.

sn.def: Wearing or furnished with an ochrea or legging; wearing boots; booted.
sn.q: A scholar undertook . . . to address himself ochreated unto the vice chancellor.

sn.def: Provided with ochrea, or sheathformed stipules, as the rhubarb, yellow dock, and knotgrass.

entry.def: See Ocherous.
See Ochery.
Yellowish white; having a faint tint of dingy yellow.
See Ochery.
See Occamy.

entries.entry:
-ock. AS. -uc
A suffix used to form diminutives; as, bullock, hillock .

entry.def: See Okra.
See Ochrea.
Same as Ochreate Ochreated.

entries.entry: Oc"ta-. A prefix meaning eight. See Octo-.

entry.ety: Gr. � with eight strings; 'okta-for 'oktw` eight) + � string, chord: cf. F. octacorde
entry.def: An instrument of eight strings; a system of eight tones.

sn.def: An atom or radical which has a valence of eight, or is octavalent.
A group of eight things.

entry.def: See Octahedral.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. �, neut. of � of the eighth day
entry.def: A fast of eight days before a great festival.

cs.cd: one in which the sides are all equal, and the angles also are all equal.

entry.ety: Gr. � eight-cornered; 'okta-for 'oktw` eight) + � an angle: cf. F. cctogone

sn.def: A plane figure of eight sides and eight angles.
Any structure (as a fortification) or place with eight sides or angles.

entry.def: Having eight sides and eight angles.
Having eight pistils or styles; octogynous.

cs.cd: borax obtained from a saturated solution in octahedral crystals, which contain five molecules of water of crystallization; distinguished from common or prismatic borax.
magnetite.

entry.def: Having eight faces or sides; of, pertaining to, or formed in, octahedrons; as, octahedral cleavage; an octahedral crystal.
Titanium dioxide occurring in acute octahedral crystals.

entry.ety: Gr.�, fr. � eight-side; 'okta-for 'oktw` eight) + � seat, base, from � to sit
entry.def: A solid bounded by eight faces. The regular octahedron is contained by eight equal equilateral triangles.
Having the parts in eights; as, an octamerous flower; octamerous mesenteries in polyps.

entry.ety: Cf.L. octameter in eight feet. See Octa-, and meter

sn.def: A verse containing eight feet; as,Deep" in|to" the | dark"ness | peer"ing, | long" I | stood" there | wond'"ring, | fear"ing.
A molecule composed of eight monomer units bound to each other, usually in a linear array; as, an octomer formed of nucleotides is called an octonucleotide.

entry.def: One of the Octandria.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. 'okta-for 'oktw` eight) + �, �, male, man
entry.def: A Linnæan class of plants, in which the flowers have eight stamens not united to one another or to the pistil.
Of or pertaining to the Octandria; having eight distinct stamens.

Any one of a group of metametric hydrocarbons (C8H18) of the methane (paraffin) series. The most important is a colorless, volatile, inflammable liquid, found in petroleum, and a constituent of gasoline or ligroin.

entry.ety: L. octangulus eight-cornered; octo eight + angulus angle
entry.def: Having eight angles; eight-angled.

entry.ety: L. octans -antis. fr. octo eight. See Octave

sn.def: The eighth part of a circle; an arc of 45 degrees.
The position or aspect of a heavenly body, as the moon or a planet, when half way between conjunction, or opposition, and quadrature, or distant from another body 45 degrees.
An instrument for measuring angles (generally called a quadrant), having an arc which measures up to 9O°, but being itself the eighth part of a circle. Cf. Sextant.
One of the eight parts into which a space is divided by three coördinate planes.

entries.entry: ‖Oc"ta*pla n.; etymol. pl., but syntactically sing. NL., fr. Gr. 'okta-for 'oktw` eight) + -pla, as in E. hexapla; cf. Gr. � eightfold A portion of the Old Testament prepared by Origen in the 3d century, containing the Hebrew text and seven Greek versions of it, arranged in eight parallel columns.

entry.def: See Octoroon.
See Octostyle.
A collection of eight books; especially, the first eight books of the Old Testament.

entry.ety: Octa- + L. valens, p. pr. See Valence
entry.def: Having a valence of eight; capable of being combined with, exchanged for, or compared with, eight atoms of hydrogen; -- said of certain atoms or radicals.

entry.note: ☞ The ratio of a musical tone to its octave above is 1:2 as regards the number of vibrations producing the tones.
entry.cs: Double octave. Mus See under Double. Octave flute Mus a small flute, the tones of which range an octave higher than those of the German or ordinary flute; -- called also piccolo. See Piccolo.
entry.ety: F., fr. L. octava an eighth, fr. octavus eighth, fr. octo eight. See Eight, and cf. Octavo Utas

sn.def: The eighth day after a church festival, the festival day being included; also, the week following a church festival.
sn.q: Theoctavesof Easter.

sd.def: The eighth tone in the scale; the interval between one and eight of the scale, or any interval of equal length; an interval of five tones and two semitones.
The whole diatonic scale itself.

sn.def: The first two stanzas of a sonnet, consisting of four verses each; a stanza of eight lines.
sn.q: With mournful melody it continued this octave.

sn.def: A small cask of wine, the eighth part of a pipe.

entry.def: Consisting of eight; eight.

entries.entry:
Oc*ta"vo n.;pl.Octavos #. L. in octavo; in in + octavo, abl. of octavus. See Octave
A book composed of sheets each of which is folded into eight leaves; hence, indicating more or less definitely a size of book so made; -- usually written 8vo or 8°.

entry.def: Having eight leaves to a sheet; as, an octavo form, book, leaf, size, etc.
Same as Octylene.

entry.ety: L. octennium a period of eight years; octo eight + annus year
entry.def: Happening every eighth year; also, lasting a period of eight years.

entry.ety: From L. octo eight, like E. duet, fr.L. duo. See Octave

sn.def: A composition for eight parts, usually for eight solo instruments or voices.
A group of eight singers or eight musicians.

entry.def: Of the eighth degree or order.

def2.def: A quantic of the eighth degree.

entry.ety: Cf. F. octil, a. See Octant
entry.def: Same as Octant, 2.

entry.ety: L. octo eight + -illion, as in E. million: cf. F. octillion
entry.def: According to the French method of numeration (which method is followed also in the United States) the number expressed by a unit with twenty-seven ciphers annexed. According to the English method, the number expressed by a unit with forty-eight ciphers annexed. See Numeration.

entries.entry:
Oc"to- Oc"ta- . L. octo eight, Gr. 'oktw`, with a combining form 'okta-. Cf. Eight
A combining form meaning eight; as in octodecimal, octolocular.

entry.def: A salt of an octoic acid; a caprylate.

entry.ety: L., the eighth month of the primitive Roman year, which began in March, fr. octo eight: cf. F. Octobre. See Octave

sn.def: The tenth month of the year, containing thirty-one days.
Ale or cider made in that month.
sn.q: The country gentlemen had a posset or drink they called October.

entry.def: Octocerata.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. 'oktw` eight + �, a horn
entry.def: A suborder of Cephalopoda including Octopus Argonauta, and allied genera, having eight arms around the head; -- called also Octopoda.
See Octachord.

entry.ety: L. octodecim eighteen. See Octavo Decimal, and -mo
entry.def: Having eighteen leaves to a sheet; as, an octodecimo form, book, leaf, size, etc.

entries.entry: Oc`to*dec"i*mo n.; pl.Octodecimos. A book composed of sheets each of which is folded into eighteen leaves; hence; indicating more or less definitely a size of book, whose sheets are so folded; -- usually written 18mo or 18°, and called eighteenmo.

entry.def: Having eight teeth.
Of or pertaining to the Octodontidæ, a family of rodents which includes the coypu, and many other South American species.
See Octahedral.

entry.ety: Octo- + root of L. findere to split: cf. F. octofide
entry.def: Cleft or separated into eight segments, as a calyx.
A marrying eight times.
A person eighty years, or more, of age.

entry.ety: L. octogenarius, from octogeni eighty each, octoginta eighty, fr. octo eight. See Eight Eighty
entry.def: Of eighty years of age.
entry.q: Being thenoctogenary.

entry.def: A pecuniary compensation for an injury, of eight times the value of the thing.
See Octagonal.

entry.ety: NL., from Gr. 'oktw` eight + gynh` a woman, female
entry.def: A Linnaean order of plants having eight pistils.
Having eight pistils; octagynous.
Pertaining to, derived from, or resembling, octane; -- used specifically, to designate any one of a group of acids, the most important of which is called caprylic acid.
Having eight cells for seeds.
A colorless liquid hydrocarbon of the octylene series, occurring in Caucasian petroleum.

entry.ety: L. octonarius, fr. octoni eight each, fr. octo eight
entry.def: Of or pertaining to the number eight.

entry.ety: L. octoni eight each + E. ocular
entry.def: Having eight eyes.
An animal having eight feet, as a spider.
Having eight petals or flower leaves.

entry.ety: Gr. � eight-footed; 'oktw` eight + poy`s podo`s, foot: cf. F. octopode
entry.def: One of the Octocerata.
Same as Octocerata.
Same as Arachnida.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. 'oktw` eight + � a little foot
entry.def: Same as Octocerata.

sn.def: A genus of eight-armed cephalopods, including numerous species, some of them of large size. See Devilfish.
Any member of the genus Octopus.
Something resembling an octopus in having numerous controlling arms or branches that reach widely and influence many activities; -- used mostly of organizations, such as diversified corporations.

entry.def: Having eight rays.

entry.ety: L. octo eight + -roon, as in quadroon
entry.def: The offspring of a quadroon and a white person; a mestee.
Containing eight seeds.
In eight vertical ranks, as leaves on a stem.

entry.ety: Octo- + Gr. � a pillar: cf. F. octostyle
entry.def: Having eight columns in the front; -- said of a temple or portico. The Parthenon is octostyle, but most large Greek temples are hexastyle. See Hexastyle.

entry.ety: L. octosyllabus. See Octo-, and Syllable
entry.def: Consisting of or containing eight syllables.
Octosyllabic.
A word of eight syllables.

entry.ety: octo- eight + thorp Etymology of thorp uncertain. (ca. 1965). See quote below. Possibly derived from octalthorpe or octotherponce used by the Bell System?)
entry.def: A typographic symbol (#) having two vertical lines intersected by two horizontal lines. It is also called the crosshatch hash numeral sign and number sign; in the U. S. it is commonly called the pound sign, especially to designate the symbol as used on digital telephone dials, but this can be confusing to Europeans who think of the pound sign as the symbol for the British pound. It is commonly used as a symbol for the word number; as in #36 (meaning: number thirty-six.
entry.q: octothorp Otherwise known as the numeral sign. It has also been used as a symbol for the pound avoirdupois, but this usage is now archaic. In cartography, it is also a symbol for village: eight fields around a central square, and this is the source of its name. Octothorp means eight fields.

entry.def: A hypothetical radical (C7H15.CO.), regarded as the essential residue of octoic acid.

sn.def: A privilege granted by the sovereign authority, as the exclusive right of trade granted to a guild or society; a concession.
A tax levied in money or kind at the gate of a French city on articles brought within the walls.

entry.ety: From L. octo eight + -uor, as in L. quatuor
entry.def: See Octet.

entry.ety: L. octuplus; cf. Gr. �: cf. F. octuple
entry.def: Eightfold.
A hypothetical hydrocarbon radical regarded as an essential residue of octane, and as entering into its derivatives; as, octyl alcohol.
Any one of a series of metameric hydrocarbons (C8H16) of the ethylene series. In general they are combustible, colorless liquids.
Pertaining to, derived from, or containing, octyl; as, octylic ether.

entry.ety: L. ocularis ocularius, fr. oculus the eye: cf. F. oculaire. See Eye, and cf. Antler Inveigle

sn.def: Depending on, or perceived by, the eye; received by actual sight; personally seeing or having seen; as, ocular proof.
sn.q: Thomas was an ocular witness of Christ's death.

sn.def: Of or pertaining to the eye; optic.

entry.def: The eyepiece of an optical instrument, as of a telescope or microscope.
By the eye, or by actual sight.
Of or pertaining to the eye; ocular; optic; as, oculary medicines.

sn.def: Furnished with eyes.
Having spots or holes resembling eyes; ocellated.

entry.ety: L. oculus the eye + form: cf. F. oculiforme
entry.def: In the form of an eye; resembling an eye; as, an oculiform pebble.

entry.ety: NL., fr. L. oculus the eye
entry.def: A genus of tropical corals, usually branched, and having a very volid texture.

entry.ety: NL., fr. NL. oculina the name of a typical genus
entry.def: A suborder of corals including many reef-building species, having round, starlike calicles.

entry.ety: L. oculus the eye: cf. F. oculiste
entry.def: One skilled in treating diseases of the eye.

entries.entry: Oc"u*lo-. A combining form from L. oculus the eye.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to the movement of the eye; -- applied especially to the common motor nerves (or third pair of cranial nerves) which supply many of the muscles of the orbit.
Of or pertaining to the region of the eye and the nose; as, the oculonasal, or nasal, nerve, one of the branches of the ophthalmic.

entries.entry:
‖Oc"u*lus n.; pl.Oculi #. L., an eye
An eye.
Arch A round window, usually a small one.
Bot A leaf bud.

entry.def: One of a tribe of crabs which live in holes in the sand along the seashore, and run very rapidly, -- whence the name.

An alleged force or natural power, supposed, by Reichenbach and others, to produce the phenomena of mesmerism, and to be developed by various agencies, as by magnets, heat, light, chemical or vital action, etc.; -- called also odyle or the odylic force.
entry.q: That od force of German Reichenbach Which still, from female finger tips, burnt blue.

entry.ety: Cf. Icel. ē�al, Dan. odel allodial, Sw. odal
entry.def: Among the early and medieval Teutonic peoples, esp. Scandinavians, the heritable land held by the various odalmen constituting a family or kindred of freeborn tribesmen; also, the ownership of such land. The odal was subject only to certain rights of the family or kindred in restricting the freedom of transfer or sale and giving certain rights of redemption in case of change of ownership by inheritance, etc., and perhaps to other rights of the kindred or the tribe. Survivals of the early odal estates and tenure exist in Orkney and Shetland, where it is usually called by the variant form udal.
Noting, or pert. to, odal land or ownership.

entry.ety: F., fr. Turk. odaliq chambermaid, fr. oda chamber, room
entry.def: A female slave or concubine in the harem of the Turkish sultan.
entry.q: Not of those that men desire, sleekOdalisques, or oracles of mode.

entry.def: A man or woman having odal, or able to share in it by inheritance.

entry.ety: OE. odde, fr. Icel. oddi a tongue of land, a triangle, an odd number (from the third or odd angle, or point, of a triangle), orig., a point, tip; akin to Icel. oddr point, point of a weapon, Sw. udda odd, udd point, Dan. od AS. ord, OHG. ort, G. ort place (cf. E. point, for change of meaning)

sn.def: Not paired with another, or remaining over after a pairing; without a mate; unmatched; single; as, an odd shoe; an odd glove.
Not divisible by 2 without a remainder; not capable of being evenly paired, one unit with another; as, 1, 3, 7, 9, 11, etc., are odd numbers.
sn.q: I hope good luck lies in odd numbers.

sn.def: Left over after a definite round number has been taken or mentioned; indefinitely, but not greatly, exceeding a specified number; extra.
sn.q: Sixteen hundred and odd years after the earth was made, it was destroyed in a deluge.
There are yet missing of your company Some few odd lads that you remember not.

sn.def: Remaining over; unconnected; detached; fragmentary; hence, occasional; inconsiderable; as, odd jobs; odd minutes; odd trifles.
Different from what is usual or common; unusual; singular; peculiar; unique; strange.
sn.q: Anoddaction.
Anoddexpression.
The odd man, to perform all things perfectly, is, in my poor opinion, Joannes Sturmius.
Patients have sometimes coveted odd things.
Locke's Essay would be a very odd book for a man to make himself master of, who would get a reputation by critical writings.
sn.syn: Quaint; unmatched; singular; unusual; extraordinary; strange; queer; eccentric; whimsical; fantastical; droll; comical. See Quaint.

sn.def: A person with an unusual or odd personality; an eccentric person.
Anything unusual in its class.
sn.q: Pluto is an oddball among its eight sister planets. It's the smallest in both size and mass, and has the most elliptical orbit. It moves in a plane tilted markedly away from the other planets' orbits. Moreover, Pluto is the only planet made almost entirely of ice.

entry.def: Eccentric; very unusual; strange; bizarre; as, an oddball request.

entries.entry: Odd" Fel`low. A member of a secret order, or fraternity, styled the Independent Order of Odd Fellows, established for mutual aid and social enjoyment.

odd"i*ty ŏd"ĭ*t� n.; pl.Oddities ŏd"ĭ*tĭz.
The quality or state of being odd; singularity; queerness; peculiarity; as, oddity of dress, manners, and the like. That infinitude of oddities in him.
That which is odd; as, a collection of oddities .

entry.def: varied and irregularly performed; -- of paid labor; as, he found only odd-job employment.

sn.def: In an odd manner; unevenly.
In a peculiar manner; strangely; queerly; curiously.
sn.q: A figure a little moreoddlyturned.
A great black substance, . . . very oddly shaped.

sn.def: In a manner measured by an odd number.

entries.entry:
Odd"ment n.
Odd + -ment
An odd thing, or one that is left over, disconnected, fragmentary, or the like; something that is separated or disconnected from its fellows; Specif.: Printing Any separate small part or page in a book, other than the text, such as the title page, contents, etc. A miscellaneous collection of riddles, charms, gnomic verses, and “oddments” of different kinds.
A piece of cloth that is left over after the rest has been used or sold. end, remainder, remnant, scrap.
Something unusual, and perhaps worthy of collecting. curio, curiosity, oddity, peculiarity, rarity, collectible.
pl. Odds and ends; a motley assortment of things. odds and ends, melange, farrago, ragbag, hodgepodge, hotchpotch, omnium-gatherum.

sn.def: The state of being odd, or not even.
sn.q: Take but one from three, and you not only destroy the oddness, but also the essence of that number.

sn.def: Singularity; strangeness; eccentricity; irregularity; uncouthness; as, the oddness of dress or shape; the oddness of an event.

entry.def: Pinnate with a single leaflet at the apex; -- of a leaf shape.

entry.cs: At odds in dispute; at variance. “These squires at odds did fall.” Spenser. “He flashes into one gross crime or other, that sets us all at odds.” Shak. It is odds it is probable; same as odds are, but no longer used. Obs Jer. Taylor. odds are it is probable; as, odds are he will win the gold medal. Odds and ends that which is left; remnants; fragments; refuse; scraps; miscellaneous articles. “My brain is filled . . . with all kinds of odds and ends.” W. Irving. slim odds low odds; poor chances; as, there are slim odds he will win any medal.

sn.def: Difference in favor of one and against another; excess of one of two things or numbers over the other; inequality; advantage; superiority; hence, excess of chances; probability. The odds are often expressed by a ratio; as, the odds are three to one that he will win, i. e. he will win three times out of four
sn.q: Preëminent by so muchodds.
The fearfuloddsof that unequal fray.
The odds Is that we scarce are men and you are gods.
There appeared, at least, four to one odds against them.
All the odds between them has been the different scope . . . given to their understandings to range in.
Judging is balancing an account and determining on which side the odds lie.

sn.def: Quarrel; dispute; debate; strife; -- chiefly in the phrase at odds.
sn.q: Set them into confounding odds.
I can not speak Any beginning to this peevish odds.

cs.cd: one who makes, or who traffics in, odes; -- used contemptuously.

entry.ety: F., fr. L. ode oda, Gr. 'w,dh` a song, especially a lyric song, contr. fr. 'aoidh`, fr. 'aei`dein to sing; cf. Skr. vad to speak, sing. Cf. Comedy Melody Monody
entry.def: A short poetical composition proper to be set to music or sung; a lyric poem; esp., now, a poem characterized by sustained noble sentiment and appropriate dignity of style.
entry.q: Hangs odes upon hawthorns and elegies on brambles.
O! run; prevent them with thy humble ode, And lay it lowly at his blessed feet.

entry.def: A little or short ode.
The lower house of the Norwegian Storthing. See Legislature.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. �, fr. �: cf. F. odéon. See Ode
entry.def: A kind of theater in ancient Greece, smaller than the dramatic theater and roofed over, in which poets and musicians submitted their works to the approval of the public, and contended for prizes; -- hence, in modern usage, the name of a hall for musical or dramatic performances.
See Odeon.
Fitted to excite hatred; hateful; odious.
Of or pertaining to od. See Od.

entry.ety: Icel. �; prob.akin to E. wood, a. See Wednesday
entry.def: The supreme deity of the Scandinavians; -- the same as Woden, of the German tribes.
entry.q: There in the Temple, carved in wood, The image of great Odin stood.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to Odin.
Worship of Odin; broadly, the Teutonic heathenism.
entry.q: Odinism was valor; Christianism was humility, a nobler kind of valor.

entry.ety: L. odiosus, from odium hatred: cf. F. odieux. See Odium

sn.def: Hateful; deserving or receiving hatred; as, an odious name, system, vice.
sn.q: All wickedness will be mostodious.
He rendered himself odious to the Parliament.

sn.def: Causing or provoking hatred, repugnance, or disgust; offensive; disagreeable; repulsive; as, an odious sight; an odious smell.
sn.q: The odious side of that polity.
sn.syn: Hateful; detestable; abominable; disgusting; loathsome; invidious; repulsive; forbidding; unpopular.

entry.def: A writer of an ode or odes.

cs.cd: the enmity peculiar to contending theologians.

entry.usage: Odium Hatred. We exercise hatred; we endure odium. The former has an active sense, the latter a passive one. We speak of having a hatred for a man, but not of having an odium toward him. A tyrant incurs odium. The odium of an offense may sometimes fall unjustly upon one who is innocent.
entry.ety: L., fr. odi I hate. Cf. Annoy Noisome

sn.def: Intense hatred or dislike; loathing; abhorrence.
The quality that provokes hatred; offensiveness.
sn.q: She threw the odium of the fact on me.

sn.def: The state of being intensely hated as the result of some despicable action; opprobrium; disrepute; discredit; reproach mingled with contempt; as, his conduct brought him into odium, or, brought odium upon him.
sn.q: I wish I had a cause to seek him there, To oppose his hatred fully.
You have . . . dexterously thrown some of the odium of your polity upon that middle class which you despise.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Odized ōd"īzd or ŏd"īzd; p. pr. & vb. n. Odizing
entry.def: To charge with od. See Od.
A volatile liquid obtained by boiling sulphur with linseed oil. It has an unpleasant garlic odor.
A genus of North American deer.

sn.def: A machine for registering the distance traversed by a vehicle or pedestrain.
A device for recording the length and rapidity of stride and the number of steps taken by a walker.

entry.ety: Gr. "odo`metron "odo`metros, an instrument for measuring distance; "odo`s way + me`tron measure: cf. F. odométre hodométre. See also hodometer
entry.def: An instrument attached to a vehicle or connected, as by a flexible cable, to the wheel of a vehicle, which measures the distance traversed.

sn.def: A hodometer.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to the odometer, or to measurements made with it.
Serving to measure distance on a road.
Measurement of distances by the odometer.
The division of insects that includes the dragon flies.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. �; 'odoy`s 'odo`ntos, a tooth + 'a`lgos pain
entry.def: Toothache.
Of or pertaining to odontalgia.
Same as Odontalgia.
Cutting of the teeth; dentition.

entries.entry: O*don"to-. A combining form from Gr. 'odoy`s 'odo`ntos, a tooth.

sn.def: One of the more or less columnar cells on the outer surface of the pulp of a tooth; an odontoplast. They are supposed to be connected with the formation of dentine.
One of the cells which secrete the chitinous teeth of Mollusca.

entry.ety: NL., from Gr. 'odoy`s 'odo`ntos, a tooth + kh^tos a whale
entry.def: A subdivision of Cetacea, including the sperm whale, dolphins, etc.; the toothed whales.

entry.ety: Odonto- + root of Gr. gi`gnesqai to be born: cf: F. odontogénie
entry.def: Generation, or mode of development, of the teeth.
An instrument for marking or laying off the outlines of teeth of gear wheels.
Of or pertaining to odontography.
A description of the teeth.

cs.cd: a separate bone, in many reptiles, corresponding to the odontoid process.
the anterior process of the centrum of the second vertebra, or axis, in birds and mammals. See Axis.

entry.ety: Gr. �; 'odoy`s 'odo`ntos, a tooth + e'i^dos form: cf. F. odontoïde
entry.def: Having the form of a tooth; toothlike.
Of or pertaining to the odontoid bone or to the odontoid process.

entry.ety: NL., from Gr. 'odoy`s 'odo`ntos, a tooth + � a furrow
entry.def: An extinct order of ostrichlike aquatic birds having teeth, which are set in a groove in the jaw. It includes Hesperornis, and allied genera. See Hesperornis.
A fossil tooth colored a bright blue by phosphate of iron. It is used as an imitation of turquoise, and hence called bone turquoise.
The science which treats of the teeth, their structure and development.
Same as Cephalophora.

A special structure found in the mouth of most mollusks, except bivalves. It consists of several muscles and a cartilage which supports a chitinous radula, or lingual ribbon, armed with teeth. Also applied to the radula alone. See Radula.
Having an odontophore.

entry.ety: Odonto- + Gr. pla`ssein to form, mold
entry.def: An odontoblast.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. 'odoy`s 'odo`ntos, a tooth + pte`ryx a wing
entry.def: An extinct Eocene bird having the jaws strongly serrated, or dentated, but destitute of true teeth. It was found near London.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. 'odoy`s 'odo`ntos, a tooth + �, �, a bird
entry.def: A group of Mesozoic birds having the jaws armed with teeth, as in most other vertebrates. They have been divided into three orders: Odontolcæ, Odontotormæ, and Saururæ.
Having toothlike mandibles; -- applied to certain insects.

entry.ety: NL., fr. 'odoy`s 'odo`ntos, a tooth + � a socket
entry.def: An order of extinct toothed birds having the teeth in sockets, as in the genus Ichthyornis. See Ichthyornis.

cs.cd: to be out of favor, or in bad repute.

entry.ety: OE. odor odour, OF. odor odour, F. odeur, fr. L. odor; akin to olere to smell, Gr. 'o`zein, Lith. ůsti. Cf. Olfactory Osmium Ozone Redolent
entry.def: Any smell, whether fragrant or offensive; scent; perfume.
entry.q: Meseemed I smelt a garden of sweet flowers, That dainty odors from them threw around.

entry.def: A perfume; a strong scent.
Yielding odors; fragrant.
An odorous substance;

a substance with a strong odor added to a dangerous substance, such as natural gas, to provide an easy detection method and a warning; as, ethyl mercaptan is used as an odorant in natural gas and propane to facilitate detection of leaks.

entry.ety: L. odoratus, p. p. of odorare to perfume, fr. odor odor
entry.def: Odorous.
Diffusing odor or scent; fragrant.

entry.ety: L. odorifer; odor odor + ferre to bear. See Odoe, and 1st Bear
entry.def: Bearing or yielding an odor; perfumed; usually, sweet of scent; fragrant; as, odoriferous spices, particles, fumes, breezes.
A pungent oily substance obtained by redistilling bone oil.
Free from odor.

entry.ety: L. odorus, fr. odor odor: cf. OF. odoros odoreux
entry.def: Having or emitting an odor or scent, esp. a sweet odor; fragrant; sweet-smelling.
entry.q: Odorousbloom.
Such fragrant flowers do give most odorous smell.

entry.def: A corruption of God's; -- formerly used in oaths and ejaculatory phrases.
entry.q: Odsbodikin.
Odspity.

entry.def: See Od. Archaic.
Of or pertaining to odyle; odic; as, odylic force.

entry.ety: L. Odyssea, Gr. 'Ody`sseia, fr. 'Odyssey`s Ulysses: cf. F. Odyssée
entry.def: An epic poem attributed to Homer, which describes the return of Ulysses to Ithaca after the siege of Troy.

a diphthong, employed in the Latin language, and thence in the English language, as the representative of the Greek diphthong oi. In many words in common use, e alone stands instead of œ. Classicists prefer to write the diphthong oe separate in Latin words.
The colorless porous framework, or stroma, of red blood corpuscles from which the zooid, or hemoglobin and other substances of the corpuscles, may be dissolved out.
The various relations of animals and plants to one another and to the outer world; -- now more commonly spelled ecology.
See Economical.
See Economics.
See Economy.
See Ecumenical.

entry.ety: NL., from Gr. � a swelling, tumor, fr. � to swell
entry.def: A swelling from effusion of watery fluid in the cellular tissue beneath the skin or mucous membrance; dropsy of the subcutaneous cellular tissue.
Pertaining to, or of the nature of, edema; affected with edema.

entries.entry: ‖Œil`-de-bœuf" n.; pl. Œils-de-bœuf # . F., lit., eye of an ox Arch A circular or oval window; -- generally used of architecture of the 17th and 18th centuries. A famous room in the palace of Versailles bears this name, from the oval window opening into it.

entry.ety: F., lit., eye of a partridge

sn.def: Characterized by, or decorated with, small round points, spots, or rings; as, œil-de-perdrix pattern.
Having a brownish red color; -- used esp. of light-colored red wine.

entry.ety: F. œillade, fr. œel eye. See Eyelent
entry.def: A glance of the eye; an amorous look.
entry.q: She gave strange œillades and most speaking looks.

entry.def: An eye, bud, or shoot, as of a plant; an oilet.
A salt or ester of oenanthic acid; as, testosterone oenanthate is sold as an anabolic steroid; also called enanthate.

cs.cd: an acid (C6H13.CO.OH) obtained from œnanthic ether by the action of alkalies; called also n-heptanoic acid 1-heptanecarboxylic acid enanthic acid enanthylic acid and oenanthylic acid. It has the odor of sour sweat. It has the CAS registry number 111-14-8.

an ethereal substance (not to be confused with the bouquet, or aroma, of wine) found in wine lees, and consisting of a complex mixture of the ethereal salts of several of the higher acids of the acetic acid series. It has an ethereal odor, and it used in flavoring artificial wines and liquors. Called also oil of wine. See Essential oil, under Essential.

entry.ety: Gr. � the first shoot of the vine, the vine blossom, the vine; o'i`nh the vine + � bloom, 'a`nqos flower
entry.def: Having, or imparting, the odor characteristic of the bouquet of wine; specifically used, formerly, to designate an acid (oenanthic acid) whose ethereal salts were supposed to occasion the peculiar bouquet, or aroma, of old wine. Cf. Œnanthylic.
An oily substance (C6H15.CHO) obtained by the distillation of castor oil, recognized as the aldehyde of œnanthylic acid, and hence called also œnanthaldehyde.
The ketone of œnanthic acid.
A hydrocarbon radical formerly supposed to exist in œnanthic acid, now known to be identical with heptyl.
A salt of oenanthylic acid; as, potassium œnanthylate .

entry.note: Oenanthylic and oenanthic are now considered as syonyms (1999).
entry.def: Pertaining to, derived from, or containing, œnanthyl; specifically, designating an acid formerly supposed to be identical with the acid in œnanthic ether, but now known to be identical with heptanoic acid.
A colorless liquid hydrocarbon, having a garlic odor; heptine.
Of, pertaining to, or designating, an acid formerly supposed to be the acid of œnanthylic ether, but now known to be a mixture of higher acids, especially capric acid.

entry.ety: Gr. o'i^nos wine + ky`anos a dark-blue substance
entry.def: The coloring matter of red wines.
Knowledge of wine, scientific or practical.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. o'i^nos wine + � mania
entry.def: Delirium tremens.
Dipsomania.
Wine mixed with honey; mead.
See Alcoholometer.
A lover of wine.
Pertaining to an acid now called sulphovinic acid or ethyl sulphuric acid.
A contr. of Over.

entry.ety: After Hans Christian Oersted , Danish physicist
entry.def: The C. G. S. unit of magnetic reluctance or resistance, equal to the reluctance of a centimeter cube of air (or vacuum) between parallel faces. Also, a reluctance in which unit magnetomotive force sets up unit flux.
Same as Esophagus Esophageal, etc.
Of or pertaining to the gadflies.
Of or pertaining to sexual desire; -- mostly applied to brute animals; as, the œstrual period; œstrual influence.
The state of being under œstrual influence, or of having sexual desire.

entry.ety: L., a gadfly; also, frenzy, fr. Gr. � gadfly; hence, sting, fury, insane desire, frenzy

sn.def: A genus of gadflies. The species which deposits its larvæ in the nasal cavities of sheep is œstrus ovis.
A vehement desire.
The periodical sexual impulse of animals; the period during which female animals are most receptive to males; heat; rut.

entry.note: ☞ The use of the word in this sense, as applied to persons, is nearly obsolete.
☞ Of may be used in a subjective or an objective sense. “The love of God” may mean, our love for God, or God's love for us.

☞ From is the primary sense of this preposition; a sense retained in off, the same word differently written for distinction. But this radical sense disappears in most of its application; as, a man of genius; a man of rare endowments; a fossil of a red color, or of an hexagonal figure; he lost all hope of relief; an affair of the cabinet; he is a man of decayed fortune; what is the price of corn? In these and similar phrases, of denotes property or possession, or a relation of some sort involving connection. These applications, however all proceeded from the same primary sense. That which proceeds from, or is produced by, a person or thing, either has had, or still has, a close connection with the same; and hence the word was applied to cases of mere connection, not involving at all the idea of separation.

cs.cd: of importance, value, or influence.
recently; in time not long past.
formerly; in time long past.
by one's self; without help or prompting; spontaneously.
cs.q: Why, knows not Montague, that of itself England is safe, if true within itself?

entry.ety: AS. of of, from, off; akin to D. & OS. af, G. ab off, OHG. aba from, away, Icel., Dan., Sw., & Goth. af, L. ab, Gr. �, Skr. apa. Cf. Off A-2), Ab- After Epi-
entry.def: In a general sense, from, or out from; proceeding from; belonging to; relating to; concerning; -- used in a variety of applications; as:

sn.def: Denoting that from which anything proceeds; indicating origin, source, descent, and the like; as, he is of a race of kings; he is of noble blood.
sn.q: That holy thing which shall be born of thee shall be called the Son of God.
I have received of the Lord that which also I delivered unto you.

sn.def: Denoting possession or ownership, or the relation of subject to attribute; as, the apartment of the consul: the power of the king; a man of courage; the gate of heaven.
sn.q: Poorofspirit.

sn.def: Denoting the material of which anything is composed, or that which it contains; as, a throne of gold; a sword of steel; a wreath of mist; a cup of water.

Denoting part of an aggregate or whole; belonging to a number or quantity mentioned; out of; from amongst; as, of this little he had some to spare; some of the mines were unproductive; most of the company.
sn.q: It is of the Lord's mercies that we are not consumed.
It is a duty to communicate of those blessings we have received.

sn.def: Denoting that by which a person or thing is actuated or impelled; also, the source of a purpose or action; due to; as, they went of their own will; no body can move of itself; he did it of necessity.
sn.q: For it was of the Lord to harden their hearts.

sn.def: Denoting reference to a thing; about; concerning; relating to; as, to boast of one's achievements; they talked of many things.
sn.q: Knew you of this fair work?

sn.def: Denoting nearness or distance, either in space or time; from; as, within a league of the town; within an hour of the appointed time.
Denoting identity or equivalence; -- used with a name or appellation, and equivalent to the relation of apposition; as, the continent of America; the city of Rome; the Island of Cuba.
Denoting the agent, or person by whom, or thing by which, anything is, or is done; by.
sn.q: And told to her ofby] some.
He taught in their synagogues, being glorified of all.
Jesus] being forty days tempted of the devil.

sn.def: Denoting relation to place or time; belonging to, or connected with; as, men of Athens; the people of the Middle Ages; in the days of Herod.
Denoting passage from one state to another; from.
sn.q: O miserableofhappy.

sn.def: During; in the course of.
sn.q: Not be seen to wink of all the day.
My custom always of the afternoon.

entry.cs:
From off off from; off. “A live coal . . . taken with the tongs from off the altar.” Is. vi. 6. Off and on. Not constantly; not regularly; now and then; occasionally. Naut On different tacks, now toward, and now away from, the land. To be off. To depart; to escape; as, he was off without a moment's warning. To be abandoned, as an agreement or purpose; as, the bet was declared to be off . Colloq
To come off To cut off To fall off To go off
etc. See under Come Cut Fall Go, etc. To get off. To utter; to discharge; as, to get off a joke. To go away; to escape; as, to get off easily from a trial. Colloq
To take off To do a take-off on To take off
to mimic, lampoon, or impersonate. To tell off Mil to divide and practice a regiment or company in the several formations, preparatory to marching to the general parade for field exercises. Farrow. to rebuke (a person) for an improper action; to scold; to reprimand. To be well off to be in good condition.
To be ill off To be badly off
to be in poor condition.
entry.ety: OE. of, orig. the same word as R. of, prep., AS. of, adv. & prep. √194. See Of
entry.def: In a general sense, denoting from or away from; as:

sn.def: Denoting distance or separation; as, the house is a mile off .
Denoting the action of removing or separating; separation; as, to take off the hat or cloak; to cut off, to pare off, to clip off, to peel off, to tear off, to march off, to fly off, and the like.
Denoting a leaving, abandonment, departure, abatement, interruption, or remission; as, the fever goes off; the pain goes off; the game is off; all bets are off.
Denoting a different direction; not on or towards: away; as, to look off .
Denoting opposition or negation.
sn.q: The questions no way touch upon puritanism, either off or on.

entry.def: Away; begone; -- a command to depart.

entry.cs:
Off hand. See Offhand. Off side out of play; -- said when a player has got in front of the ball in a scrimmage, or when the ball has been last touched by one of his own side behind him. To be off color to be of a wrong color. to be mildly obscene.
To be off one's foodorTo be off one's feed , (Colloq. to have no appetite; to be eating less than usual.
entry.def: Not on; away from; as, to be off one's legs or off the bed; two miles off the shore.

entry.cs: Off side. The right hand side in driving; the farther side. See Gee. Cricket See Off n.

sn.def: On the farther side; most distant; on the side of an animal or a team farthest from the driver when he is on foot; in the United States, the right side; as, the off horse or ox in a team, in distinction from the nigh or near horse or ox; the off leg.

Designating a time when one is not strictly attentive to business or affairs, or is absent from his post, and, hence, a time when affairs are not urgent; as, he took an off day for fishing: an off year in politics.
sn.q: In theoffseason.

sn.def: Designating a time when one's performance is below normal; as, he had an off day.

entry.def: The side of the field that is on the right of the wicket keeper.

sn.def: The rejected or waste parts of any process, especially the inedible parts of a butchered animal, such as the viscera.
A dead body; carrion.
That which is thrown away as worthless or unfit for use; refuse; rubbish.
sn.q: The offals of other professions.

entry.def: discontinuous; not continuous. Opposite of continuous.
located outside a military base; as, off-base housing.
Of or pertaining to the professional theaters in Manhattan not in the Broadway area; performed in off-Broadway{1}.

sn.def: A group of low-budget theaters located outside the Broadway area in Manhattan.
The professional drama presented in off-Broadway theaters.

entry.def: situated away from the center or axis.
humorously vulgar; mildly obscene; risque; as, an off-color joke.

sn.def: That which is cut off.
A portion of the printed sheet, in certain sizes of books, that is cut off before folding.

entry.def: A day when things go poorly; as, I guess this is one of my off-days .
not performing or available for duties at the given moment; as, an off-duty policeman. Oposite of on-duty working, and on-the-job.
See Offense.
incapable of offending or attacking; harmless.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Offended; p. pr. & vb. n. Offending
entry.ety: OF. offendre, L. offendere offensum; obsee Ob-) + fenderein comp.) to thrust, dash. See Defend

sn.def: To strike against; to attack; to assail.
To displease; to make angry; to affront.
sn.q: A brother offended is harder to be won than a strong city.

sn.def: To be offensive to; to harm; to pain; to annoy; as, strong light offends the eye; to offend the conscience.
To transgress; to violate; to sin against.
sn.q: Marry, sir, he hath offended the law.

sn.def: To oppose or obstruct in duty; to cause to stumble; to cause to sin or to fall.
sn.q: Who hath you misboden or offended.
If thy right eye offend thee, pluck it out . . . And if thy right hand offend thee, cut it off.
Great peace have they which love thy law, and nothing shall offend them.

entry.cs: To offend against to do an injury or wrong to; to commit an offense against. “We have offended against the Lord already.” 2 Chron. xxviii. 13.

sn.def: To transgress the moral or divine law; to commit a crime; to stumble; to sin.
sn.q: Whosoever shall keep the whole law, and yet offend in one point, he is guilty of all.
If it be a sin to covet honor, I am the most offending soul alive.

sn.def: To cause dislike, anger, or vexation; to displease.
sn.q: I shall offend, either to detain or give it.

entry.def: An offender.
One who offends; one who violates any law, divine or human; a wrongdoer.
entry.q: I and my son Solomon shall be counted offenders.

entry.def: A woman who offends.

entry.note: ☞ This word, like expense, is often spelled with a c. It ought, however, to undergo the same change with expense, the reasons being the same, namely, that s must be used in offensive as in expensive, and is found in the Latin offensio, and the French offense.

cs.cd: to feel, or assume to be, injured or affronted; to become angry or hostile.
those which are used in attack, in distinction from those of defense, which are used to repel.

entry.ety: F., fr. L. offensa. See Offend

sn.def: The act of offending in any sense; esp., a crime or a sin, an affront or an injury.
sn.q: Who was delivered for our offenses, and was raised again for our justification.
I have given my opinion against the authority of two great men, but I hope without offense to their memories.

sn.def: The state of being offended or displeased; anger; displeasure; as, to cause offense .
sn.q: He was content to give them just cause of offense, when they had power to make just revenge.

sn.def: A cause or occasion of stumbling or of sin.
sn.q: Woe to that man by whom the offense cometh!

sn.def: In any contest, the act or process of attacking as contrasted with the act of defending; the offensive; as, to go on the offense .
The members of a team who have the primary responsibility to score goals, in contrast to those who have the responsibility to defend, i.e. to prevent the opposing team from scoring goal.
sn.syn: Displeasure; umbrage; resentment; misdeed; misdemeanor; trespass; transgression; delinquency; fault; sin; crime; affront; indignity; outrage; insult.

entry.def: Causing offense; displeasing; wrong; as, an offenseful act.
Unoffending; inoffensive.
That may give offense.

entry.ety: OF., fr. L. offensio an offense
entry.def: Assault; attack.

cs.cd: a leaque that requires all the parties to it to make war together against any foe, and to defend one another if attacked.

sn.def: Giving offense; causing displeasure or resentment; displeasing; annoying; as, offensive words.
Giving pain or unpleasant sensations; disagreeable; revolting; noxious; as, an offensive smell; offensive sounds.
sn.q: Offensiveto the stomach.

sn.def: Making the first attack; assailant; aggressive; hence, used in attacking; -- opposed to defensive; as, an offensive war; offensive weapons.
sn.syn: Displeasing; disagreeable; distasteful; obnoxious; abhorrent; disgusting; impertinent; rude; saucy; reproachful; opprobrious; insulting; insolent; abusive; scurrilous; assailant; attacking; invading.

cs.cd: to be the attacking party; to initiate hostilities.

entry.def: The state or posture of one who offends or makes attack; aggressive attitude; the act of the attacking party; -- opposed to defensive.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Offered; p. pr. & vb. n. Offering
entry.ety: OE. offren AS. offrian to sacrifice, fr. L. offerre; obsee OB-) + ferre to bear, bring. The English word was influenced by F. offrir to offer, of the same origin. See 1st Bear

sn.def: To present, as an act of worship; to immolate; to sacrifice; to present in prayer or devotion; -- often with up.
sn.q: Thou shalt offer every day a bullock for a sin offering for atonement.
A holy priesthood to offer up spiritual sacrifices.

sn.def: To bring to or before; to hold out to; to present for acceptance or rejection; as, to offer a present, or a bribe; to offer one's self in marriage.
sn.q: I offer thee three things.

sn.def: To present in words; to proffer; to make a proposal of; to suggest; as, to offer an opinion. With the infinitive as an objective: To make an offer; to declare one's willingness; as, he offered to help me.
To attempt; to undertake.
sn.q: All that offer to defend him.

sn.def: To bid, as a price, reward, or wages; as, to offer a guinea for a ring; to offer a salary or reward.
To put in opposition to; to manifest in an offensive way; to threaten; as, to offer violence, attack, etc.
sn.syn: To propose; propound; move; proffer; tender; sacrifice; immolate.

sn.def: To present itself; to be at hand.
sn.q: The occasion offers, and the youth complies.

sn.def: To make an attempt; to make an essay or a trial; -- used with at.
sn.q: Withoutofferingat any other remedy.
He would be offering at the shepherd's voice.
I will not offer at that I can not master.

entry.ety: Cf. F. offre, fr. offrir to offer, fr. L. offerre. See Offer v. t.

sn.def: The act of offering, bringing forward, proposing, or bidding; a proffer; a first advance.
sn.q: Thisoffercomes from mercy.

sn.def: That which is offered or brought forward; a proposal to be accepted or rejected; a sum offered; a bid.
sn.q: When offers are disdained, and love denied.

sn.def: Attempt; endeavor; essay; as, he made an offer to catch the ball.
sn.q: Someofferand attempt.

entry.def: Capable of being offered; suitable or worthy to be offered.
One who offers; esp., one who offers something to God in worship.

cs.cd: etc. See under Burnt. etc.

sn.def: The act of an offerer; a proffering.
That which is offered, esp. in divine service; that which is presented as an expiation or atonement for sin, or as a free gift; a sacrifice; an oblation; as, sin offering .
sn.q: They are polluted offerings more abhorred Than spotted livers in the sacrifice.

sn.def: A sum of money offered, as in church service; as, a missionary offering .
Personal tithes payable according to custom, either at certain seasons as Christmas or Easter, or on certain occasions as marriages or christenings.
sn.q: None] to the offering before her should go.

entries.entry:
Of"fer*to*ry n.; pl.Offertories . L. offertorium the place to which offerings were brought, in LL. offertory: cf. F. offertoire
The act of offering, or the thing offered. Obs. or R
R. C. Ch
An anthem chanted, or a voluntary played on the organ, during the offering and first part of the Mass.
That part of the Mass which the priest reads before uncovering the chalice to offer up the elements for consecration.
The oblation of the elements.
Ch. of Eng. & Prot. Epis. Ch
The Scripture sentences said or sung during the collection of the offerings.
The offerings themselves.

entry.def: Offer; proposal; overture.
entry.q: More offertures and advantages to his crown.

entry.def: not watching for possible danger; not alert; as, caught in an off-guard moment.
Instant; unprepared; ready; extemporaneous; unrehearsed; as, an offhand speech; offhand excuses; an offhand comment.

def2.def: In an offhand manner; as, he replied offhand .

sn.def: same as offhand and off-the-cuff.
sn.syn: ad-lib, extemporaneous, extemporary, extempore, offhand, off-the-cuff, unpremeditated, unrehearsed.

sn.def: Without, or seeming to be without, plan or method; casual.

entry.cs: Holy office. Same as Inquisition n., 3. Houses of office. Same as def. 7 above. Chaucer. Little office R. C. Ch an office recited in honor of the Virgin Mary. Office bearer an officer; one who has a specific office or duty to perform. Office copy Law an authenticated or certified copy of a record, from the proper office. See Certified copies, under Copy. Abbott. Office-found Law the finding of an inquest of office. See under Inquest. Office holder. See Officeholder in the Vocabulary Office hours. the hours of the day during which business is transacted at an office{5}. Office seeker. a person who is attempting to get elected to an elected office, or to get an appointment to an appointive public office.
entry.ety: F., fr. L. officium, for opificium; ops ability, wealth, help + facere to do or make. See Opulent Fact

sn.def: That which a person does, either voluntarily or by appointment, for, or with reference to, others; customary duty, or a duty that arises from the relations of man to man; as, kind offices, pious offices .
sn.q: I would I could do a good office between you.

sn.def: A special duty, trust, charge, or position, conferred by authority and for a public purpose; a position of trust or authority; as, an executive or judical office; a municipal office.
A charge or trust, of a sacred nature, conferred by God himself; as, the office of a priest under the old dispensation, and that of the apostles in the new.
sn.q: Inasmuch as I am the apostle of the Gentiles, I magnify mine office.

sn.def: That which is performed, intended, or assigned to be done, by a particular thing, or that which anything is fitted to perform; a function; -- answering to duty in intelligent beings.
sn.q: They [the eyes] resign their office and their light.
Hesperus, whose office is to bring Twilight upon the earth.
In this experiment the several intervals of the teeth of the comb do the office of so many prisms.

sn.def: The place where any kind of business or service for others is transacted; a building, suite of rooms, or room in which public officers or workers in any organization transact business; as, the register's office; a lawyer's office; the doctor's office; the Mayor's office.
The company or corporation, or persons collectively, whose place of business is in an office; as, I have notified the office .
The apartments or outhouses in which the domestics discharge the duties attached to the service of a house, as kitchens, pantries, stables, etc.
sn.q: As for the offices, let them stand at distance.

sn.def: Any service other than that of ordination and the Mass; any prescribed religious service.
sn.q: This morning was read in the church, after the office was done, the declaration setting forth the late conspiracy against the king's person.

entry.def: To perform, as the duties of an office; to discharge.
A person who holds an office; an officeholder.
One who holds an office; an officer, particularly one in the civil service; a placeman.

cs.cd: etc. See under Field General. etc.
the officer who, on a given day, has charge for that day of the guard, prisoners, and police of the post or camp; abbreviated O. D. OD, or O. O. D.
cs.mcol: Officer of the deckorOfficer of the watch
cs.cd: the officer temporarily in charge on the deck of a vessel, esp. a war vessel.

entry.ety: F. officier. See Office, and cf. Official n.

sn.def: One who holds an office; a person lawfully invested with an office, whether civil, military, or ecclesiastical; as, a church officer; a police officer; a staff officer.
sn.q: I am anofficerof state.

sn.def: Specifically, a commissioned officer, in distinction from a warrant officer or an enlisted man.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Officered; p. pr. & vb. n. Officering

sn.def: To furnish with officers; to appoint officers over.
To command as an officer; as, veterans from old regiments officered the recruits.

entries.entry: Of"fice wire`. Elec Copper wire with a strong but light insulation, used in wiring houses, etc.

entry.ety: L. officialis: cf. F. officiel. See Office, and cf. Official n.

sn.def: Of or pertaining to an office or public trust; as, official duties, or routine.
sn.q: That, in the official marks invested, you Anon do meet the senate.

sn.def: Derived from the proper office or officer, or from the proper authority; made or communicated by virtue of authority; as, an official statement or report.
Approved by authority; sanctioned by the pharmacopœia; appointed to be used in medicine; as, an official drug or preparation. Cf. Officinal.
Discharging an office or function.
sn.q: The stomach and other parts official unto nutrition.

entry.ety: L. officialis a magistrate's servant or attendant: cf. F. official. See Official a., and cf. Officer

sn.def: One who holds an office; esp., a subordinate executive officer or attendant.
An ecclesiastical judge appointed by a bishop, chapter, archdeacon, etc., with charge of the spiritual jurisdiction.

entry.def: The body of all people elected or appointed to administer a government, taken collectively.

the formal and often obscure style of writing characteristic of some government officials; bureaucratese; -- it is characterized by euphemisms, circumlocutions, vague abstractions, and circumlocutions.
The state of being official; a system of official government; also, adherence to office routine; red-tapism.
entry.q: Officialism may often drift into blunders.

entry.def: See Officialty.
to render official; as, we officialized our relationship.

By the proper officer; by virtue of the proper authority; in pursuance of the special powers vested in an officer or office; as, accounts or reports officially verified or rendered; letters officially communicated; persons officially notified.
The charge, office, court, or jurisdiction of an official.

entry.ety: L. officians, p. pr. See Officiate
entry.def: The officer who officiates or performs an office, as the burial office.
Of or pertaining to an office or an officer; official.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Officiated; p. pr. & vb. n. Officiating
entry.def: To act as an officer in performing a duty; to transact the business of an office or public trust; to conduct a public ceremony or service.
To discharge, perform, or supply, as an official duty or function.
entry.q: Merely to officiate light Round this opacous earth.

entry.def: One who officiates.

entry.note: ☞ This term is often interchanged with official, but in strict use officinal drugs are not necessarily official. See Official a., 3.
entry.ety: F., fr. L. officina a workshop, contr. fr. opificina, fr. opifex a workman; opus work + facere to make or do

sn.def: Used in a shop, or belonging to it.
Kept in stock by apothecaries; -- said of such drugs and medicines as may be obtained without special preparation or compounding; not magistral.

entry.ety: L. officiosus: cf. F. officieux. See Office

sn.def: Pertaining to, or being in accordance with, duty.
sn.q: If there were any lie in the case, it could be no more than an officious and venial one.
